I'm running JUnit through my IDE (junit.swingui.TestRunner, I then select
the class I want to run).  My classpath is setup through my IDE.  The test
class file and file I want access to are in totally separate directories.

I just found out that the root directory JUnit is using is C:\
I have no idea why, my JDK is not there, my IDE is not installed there...

So, when referencing a file beginning with a forward slash, ie,
"/images/testcases/button.gif"

JUnit was looking for the file at:
"C:\images\testcases\button.gif"

-----Original Message-----
From: nils_khare@... [mailto:nils_khare@...]
Sent: Wednesday, October 31, 2001 8:37 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit root directory question


>From where you are running your tests.
If your test class file is located at
/images
and you also are running JUnit command from
/images
then a path of "testcases//button.gif" specified in the code will
find the required GIF file.

- Nils

--- In junit@y..., "Jacob Bowers" <jacob.bowers@e...> wrote:
> Hello -
>
> When I run JUnit, where does it consider the top or root level
directory?
> In other words, I specify where the program should look for certain
files
> using something like : "/images/testcases/button.gif"
>
> When running the application normally it looks on the drive where
the JDK is
> installed.  When I run under the JUnit framework it does not seem
to be able
> to find it.
>
> Thanks!
>
> Jacob D. Bowers
> Software Engineer
